results.title: State and Main
results.creator_credit: David Mamet, Sarah Green, El Dorado Pictures, Filmtown Entertainment, Fine Line Features and Green/Renzi
results.brief_description: Written and directed by David Mamet (The Winslow boy, The Spanish prisoner) “State and Main” is a humorous tale about the making of a big-budget Hollywood film in small town USA. Walt Price is a director in pre-production for his latest flick, “The Old mill” and plagued by problems. Having fled New Hampshire under a cloud, Price and his production team arrive in Waterford, Vermont, assuming that local inhabitants will be a pushover. Among Price’s hurdles are: leading man Bob Barrenger, whose hobby is picking up underage girls; leading actress Claire who has decided not to reveal her breasts for this particular film; writer Joseph Turner White who’s script has to be altered as the old mill has burnt down, making his title (and much of his script) redundant. Some locals take to the interlopers, but others seek to manipulate them to make a buck. Town folk include Ann, an amateur writer who assists White with his screenplay; Carla, a teenager with designs on Barrenger; and George Bailey, the mayor intent on making his town famous. “State and Main” is layered with numerous stories about the creation of a Hollywood film. Starring Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Rebecca Pidgeon, William H. Macy, Sarah Jessica Parker and Julia Stiles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Mamet, Sarah Green, El Dorado Pictures, Filmtown Entertainment, Fine Line Features and Green/Renzi

results.title: Querelle [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Dieter Schidor, Gaumont and Planet Films
results.brief_description: Fassbinder’s final film is a stylised attempt to bring Jean Genet’s novel “Querelle de Brest” to the screen. Filmed in rich reds and oranges, “Querelle” is set in a hallucinatory world. The sailor Querelle is adored and loved by his Lieutenant, by the brothel-owner Lucienne and by her husband, Nono, but it isn’t until Querelle kills a man that he himself becomes ready to love. He chooses for his lover the murderer Gilles: a love which leads to a complex game of sexual betrayal and, ironically, both to tragedy and redemption. “Querelle” is like watching love unfold in the middle of a wet dream. Stars Brad Davis, Jeanne Moreau, Franco Nero and Laurent Malet. Screenplay, Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Burkhard Driest. Cinematography, Xaver Schwarzenberger and Josef Vavra. Music, Peer Raben. Editing, Juliane Lorenz and Frantz Walsch.

results.title: Traffic [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Steven Soderbergh, Edward Zwick, Laura Bickford, Marshall Herskovitz, Bedford Falls, Initial Entertainment Group (US) and USA Films
results.brief_description: Directed by Steven Soderbergh, “Traffic” is a multifaceted film, which plots at least a dozen stories, all centred around one thing - drugs. America’s war on drugs is shown to be a complex, if futile battle. The new head of the DEA, Robert Wakefield (Michael Douglas), is expected to get results in Washington with new policies. Unbeknownst to Wakefield his daughter Caroline (Erika Christensen) is addicted to crack. Meanwhile in a well-to-do suburb, Ayala (Catherine Zeta-Jones) is dismayed by her husband’s arrest, and is informed by her lawyer (Dennis Quaid) that not all of her beloved’s business dealings are legal. Two DEA agents Ray Castro (Luis Guzman) and Montel Gordon (Don Cheadle) are trying to get a drug dealer (Miguel Ferrer) to turn informer. Across the border in Mexico, Javier Rodriguez (Benicio Del Toro) is a cop trying to do the right thing whilst dealing with systemic corruption. For “Traffic” Soderbergh employs a system of different diffusions for the various locales - Washington is bathed in blue, Mexico in a blinding yellow. Winner of four Academy Awards including Best Director and Best Supporting Actor for Benicio Del Toro.

results.title: Ocean's eleven
results.creator_credit: Lewis Milestone, Dorchester and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Danny Ocean (Frank Sinatra) gathers together a group of ex-army buddies for an ambitious heist - the robbery of several casinos on New Year’s eve. His gang include playboy Jimmy (Peter Lawler), lounge lizard Sam (Dean Martin) and garbage man Josh (Sammy Davis Jnr) among others. At the time of production these very actors made up the crew known as the Rat Pack. Led by Sinatra, the Rat Pack were infamous for their carousing, womanising, drinking, entertaining and swinging image and in this film they do not stray far from their real life personas. “Ocean’s eleven” is not a film that treats the heist genre seriously in that it lacks any real tension of great films of that type. Rather, the film’s joys are derived from its 1960s aesthetic, the machinations of the sartorial Rat Pack at play, and the musical numbers courtesy of Davis and Martin. Also stars: Angie Dickinson , Cesar Romero, Shirley MacLaine, Joey Bishop and Red Skelton.

results.title: Blow
results.creator_credit: Ted Demme, Denis Leary, Joel Stillerman and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Produced and directed by the late Ted Demme, Blow hurtles through three heady decades in the life of notorious drug dealer George Jung (Johnny Depp). From Jung’s early days selling marijuana on California beaches, through to multi-million dollar cocaine deals with gun-toting Columbians, Demme takes full advantage of the changing music, clothes and hairstyles of the 60’s, 70’s and 80’s. The fast pace, black humour and violence of the drug world is tempered by the gentler story of Jung’s failed relationships with his father (Ray Liotta) and his daughter. Cast includes Penelope Cruz, Rachael Griffiths, Paul Reubens, Jordi Molla and Franka Potente.

results.title: Blood oath = Prisoners of the sun [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Brian A. Williams, Charles Waterstreet, Denis Whitburn and Siege Productions
results.brief_description: The Ambon tribunal which tried 91 Japanese soldiers for war crimes against Australian prisoners during World War II provided the basis for the script co-written by the son of John Williams who was the Australian prosecuting officer (Captain Cooper in the film, played by Bryan Brown). The film attempts to portray the perplexing issue of war guilt, against the background of international power politics, through the rhetoric of courtroom drama. It can usefully be compared with the Japanese documentary “The Tokyo Trial” (1984), the second half of which deals with the trial of 28 alleged war criminals. Cast also includes George Takei, Terry O’Quinn, John Bach, John Polson, Russell Crowe, Toshi Shioya, John Clarke and Deborah Unger. In English and Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Phantom of the paradise [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma, Edward Pressman, Harbour productions and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Director Brian De Palma offer’s up a colourful variation on The Phantom of the Opera in this outrageous Faustian parody of the 70’s rock scene. Paul Williams stars (and also acts as the films composer) as Swan an outlandish record producer who after hearing the latest composition from struggling composer Winslow Leach (William Finley), conspires to steal the piece for the opening of his latest nightclub, the Paradise. Leach catches on to Swans dastardly plan and breaks into Swans Death Records studio in order to destroy the pirated copies of his work. Unfortunately a horrible accident with the vinyl press leaves Leach grossly disfigured, thus transforming him into the Phantom of the Paradise. This masked spook then decides to exact his own brand of revenge, determined to ruin Swans latest glam rock show. Intitialy ignored and misunderstood on it’s first release, Phantom of the Paradise went on to aquire a loyal cult following, who laped up the skewered mix of horror, glam rock and music industry parody. Cast includes: Jessica Harper, George Memmoli, Gerritt Graham.

results.title: Sisters [NTSC] [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma, Edward Pressman and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: Brian De Palma’s first foray into the horror genre continues the directors fascination with Alfred Hitchcock, serving up his own twisted take on Hitchcock’s seminal shocker, Psycho and a bit of Rear window thrown in for good measure. (Hitchcock’s long time composer Bernard Herrmann also provides the score for Sisters) Sisters gets off to an auspicious start with a bizarre game show where we first meet the shy and introverted Danielle (Margot Kidder). On this rather perverse show (which seems to centre around voyeurism, a favorite De Palma theme) she meets Phillip (Lisle Wilson). The two end up back at Danielle’s apartment, much to the displeasure of her ex-husband (William Finley) and her rather unhinged twin sister Dominique (also played by Kidder). Not to give anything away, Phillip is brutally murdered soon after, which is witnessed by her journalist neighbour Grace (Jennifer Salt). Unfortunately Grace has a hard time convincing the authorities that a murder has taken place when the body mysteriously disappears out of Danielle’s apartment. De Palma reaches deep into his cinematic bag of tricks, offering a dazzling display of split-screens, flashbacks, superimposed imagery and lurid dream sequences, in this enthralling slice of grand guignol. Cast includes: Charles Durning, Dolph Sweet, Lisle Wilson.

results.title: Boycott = Baycot [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Mohsen Makhmalbaf received international renown and attention in the 1990s with a series of films, such as “Salaam Cinema”, “Gabbeh” and “A Moment of Innocence”, that placed him in the forefront of stylists and artists working in Iranian post-revolutionary cinema. “Boycott” is an early feature, his fourth, made a few years after the Islamic Revolution transformed Iranian society. Heavily influenced by Costas-Gavras’ early radical films, in particular “Z”, the relentless action, violence and over-wrought acting of “Boycott” will come as a surprise to viewers who only know Makhmalbaf’s later work. However, though it does betray the serious strictures of budget and resources affecting Iranian cinema at the time, “Boycott” is nevertheless an engrossing political thriller about the suffering and disillusionment experienced by Valeh (Mohammad Kasebi), a revolutionary agitator in pre-Revolutionary Tehran. The film starts with Valeh’s comrades brutally killed by the Shah’ notorious secret police, SAVAK. Taken to prison, Valeh encounters a horrific brutal system of torture and dehumanisation. Concerned for the welfare of his wife and new-born child, Valeh finds himself being asked by his fellow Communist prisoners to take on a role as a martyr to the cause of liberation. But distraught for his family, fearful for his life and increasingly being driven insane by torture and solitary confinement, Valeh begins to reject the tenets of Marxism. Makhmalbaf was himself imprisoned under the Pahlavi regime, and Valeh’s intellectual trajectory from Marxism to Islamic radical spiritualism, mirrors the filmmakers own personal history as a working-class agitator who became a leading artist of the Iranian Revolution. Valeh’s spiritual transcendence is rendered obliquely, but unlike, for example, the spiritual cinema of Tarkovsky, spiritual concerns do not outweigh the importance of politics or of Valeh’s terror of his increasing madness. As the chilling final scene makes clear - in a stunningly executed balletic sequence which again recalls Gavras - the savagery of the Shah’s regime demands agitation and revolt. “Boycott” is a film that veers from moments of stark beauty to thriller melodramatics, but it is a crucial work in the development of a key contemporary director. In Farsi with English subtitles.
results.description: Mohsen Makhmalbaf received international renown and attention in the 1990s with a series of films, such as “Salaam Cinema”, “Gabbeh” and “A Moment of Innocence”, that placed him in the forefront of stylists and artists working in Iranian post-revolutionary cinema. “Boycott” is an early feature, his fourth, made a few years after the Islamic Revolution transformed Iranian society. Heavily influenced by Costas-Gavras’ early radical films, in particular “Z”, the relentless action, violence and over-wrought acting of “Boycott” will come as a surprise to viewers who only know Makhmalbaf’s later work. However, though it does betray the serious strictures of budget and resources affecting Iranian cinema at the time, “Boycott” is nevertheless an engrossing political thriller about the suffering and disillusionment experienced by Valeh (Mohammad Kasebi), a revolutionary agitator in pre-Revolutionary Tehran. The film starts with Valeh’s comrades brutally killed by the Shah’ notorious secret police, SAVAK. Taken to prison, Valeh encounters a horrific brutal system of torture and dehumanisation. Concerned for the welfare of his wife and new-born child, Valeh finds himself being asked by his fellow Communist prisoners to take on a role as a martyr to the cause of liberation. But distraught for his family, fearful for his life and increasingly being driven insane by torture and solitary confinement, Valeh begins to reject the tenets of Marxism. Makhmalbaf was himself imprisoned under the Pahlavi regime, and Valeh’s intellectual trajectory from Marxism to Islamic radical spiritualism, mirrors the filmmakers own personal history as a working-class agitator who became a leading artist of the Iranian Revolution. Valeh’s spiritual transcendence is rendered obliquely, but unlike, for example, the spiritual cinema of Tarkovsky, spiritual concerns do not outweigh the importance of politics or of Valeh’s terror of his increasing madness. As the chilling final scene makes clear - in a stunningly executed balletic sequence which again recalls Gavras - the savagery of the Shah’s regime demands agitation and revolt. “Boycott” is a film that veers from moments of stark beauty to thriller melodramatics, but it is a crucial work in the development of a key contemporary director. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: 1900 = Novecento = Millenovecento [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Bernardo Bertolucci, Alberto Grimaldi, Artemis Productions, Les Productions Artistes Associes and Produzioni Europee Associati
results.brief_description: On the eve of the new twentieth century two young boys are born on the same estate in northern Italy. Olmo is the bastard son of the peasants who work the land; Alfredo is the landowner’s child. Initially friends as boys, when Olmo and Alfredo become adults (played respectively by Gerard Depardieu and Robert de Niro), they find that the stark differences of class, status and politics estrange them from one another. Olmo becomes a Communist and is involved in revolutionary politics. Alfredo finds himself drawn into fascism, even as his bohemian wife (Dominique Sanda) finds herself increasingly horrified by the excesses of the fascist thugs. Bertolucci’s vivid baroque epic dramatises the tumultuous history of modern Italy through the personal struggles of the two men. This is an epic dedicated to the European working-classes, but at the film’s centre there is a contradiction between Bertolucci’s avowed aim to make a populist epic spectacle and his intellectual and ethical commitment to dense Marxist aesthetics and polemics. If the film itself never comfortably overcomes this contradiction, lurching from intimate poetic scenes of friendship and betrayal to vulgar and vivid gothic grand guignol (in particular scenes featuring Donald Sutherland and Laura Betti as a perverse sado-masochistic fascist couple) what is undeniable are the resonances and captivating beauty of Bertolucci’s epic vision: at times it is as if he wishes to distill the essence of time, history and revolution in his mise-en-scene. What also remains unforgettable is the rich depth of the characters in this film. Depardieu and de Niro both give heroic performances, as does Sterling Hayden and Burt Lancaster as the respective patriarchal heads of the peasantry and of the landowners. Apart from being a dialectician’s‘s epic about class struggle and Italian history, “1900” is also one of cinema’s most tender explorations of the complexities and love involved in friendship. This mad, confused sweeping saga finally climaxes with an imagined re-writing of history where Communism liberates forever the peasant and working classes of Italy. But for all the ludicrous impossibility and naivety of this climax, the film ends on a note of sublime transcendence. This is classic epic cinema re-imagined by a Marxist poet. The musical score is by Enno Morricone. The ravishing cinematography by Vittorio Storaro. In Italian with English subtitles.
